data: Large block of yellow tuff, broken in 8 pieces when found, subsequently restored and set together in plaster. Most of the block is preserved, damaged at the left and right ends, with some of the left half of the face and lower edge missing. The inscribed field (108 cm wide) is cut back from the right and left margins; the upper surface is finished with traces of clamp holes for the fitting of a block above. The rear is uneven.
11 lines of Greek, filling the finished recessed field from the top and extending fully to both margins, with vacat at the end of the last line and below.
Found by Cavallari in 1871 in the left anta of the entrance to the adyton of Temple G (Zeus), Selinunte
On display, ground floor, Palermo archaeological museum
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J.Prag 23.05.2022
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J.Prag 21.07.2017
Partially reopened following extensive restoration work. Comprehensive collection of archaeological material, predominantly from the West of the island, with an important Etruscan collection.
Centre of Palermo, Piazza Olivella 24, 90100 - Palermo

Renato Arena, Iscrizioni Greche Archaiche di Sicilia e Magna Grecia. Iscrizioni di Sicilia. I. Iscrizioni di Megara Iblea e Selinunte, 2nd ed., vol. 1, 5 voll. (Pisa: Nistri Lischi, 1996)
Giacomo Manganaro, «Studi di epigrafia siceliota», Rendiconti dell’Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei. Classe di Scienze morali, storiche e filologiche 9.7 (1996): 27–63

Antonietta Brugnone, «L’iscrizione del Tempio G di Selinunte e le tradizioni sui responsi oracolari delfici», in Sicilia Epigraphica, a c. di M. I. Gulletta, vol. 1, 2 voll. (Pisa: Edizioni della Normale, 1999), 129–39

Large block of yellow tuff, broken in 8 pieces when found, subsequently restored and set together in plaster. Most of the block is preserved, damaged at the left and right ends, with some of the left half of the face and lower edge missing. The inscribed field (108 cm wide) is cut back from the right and left margins; the upper surface is finished with traces of clamp holes for the fitting of a block above. The rear is uneven.

tuff (yellow) block 43.5 139.5 24.5

11 lines of Greek, filling the finished recessed field from the top and extending fully to both margins, with vacat at the end of the last line and below.

chiselled Line 1-11 25-30 Interlineation line 1 to 2 Selinus Selinunte 37.58337, 12.82522 475—450 BCE Found by Cavallari in 1871 in the left anta of the entrance to the adyton of Temple G (Zeus), Selinunte37.5881651,12.8335283 On display, ground floor, Palermo archaeological museum Photographed, but no formal autopsy

διὰ το̄̀ς θεο̄̀ς το̄́σδε νικο͂ντι τοὶ Σελινο̄́ν τιοι διὰ τὸν Δία νικο͂μες καὶ διὰ τὸν Φόβον καὶ διὰ hερακλέα καὶ δι’ Ἀπόλλο̄να καὶ διὰ Ποτ ειδᾶνα καὶ διὰ Τυνδαρίδας καὶ δι᾿ Ἀθα ναίαν καὶ διὰ Μαλοφόρον καὶ διὰ Πασικ ράτειαν καὶ διὰ το̄̀ς ἄλλο̄ς θεο̄̀ς διὰ δὲ Δία μάλιστα φιλίας δὲ γενομένας ἐν χρυσ έο̄ι ἐλάμεν τὰ δ᾿ ἔτι ὀνύματα ταῦτα κολ άψαντες εἰς τὸ Ἀπολλο̄́νιον κάθθεμε ν τὸ Διὸς προγράψαντες τὸ δὲ χρυσίον hεξε̄́κοντα ταλάντο̄ν ἐ͂μεν
Text of IGPalermo

It is through the gods listed here that the Selinuntines win victory. Through Zeus we conquer and through Phobos and through Herakles and through Apollo and through Poseidon and through the Tyndaridai and through Athena and through Malophoros and through Pasikrateia and through the other gods, but through Zeus above all. Since there is friendship (it is resolved), that having forged in gold, and having engraved these names, to dedicate in the Apollonion, having written the name of Zeus in first place; and that the gold be sixty talents.

English translation

Jonathan Prag

It is through the gods listed here that the Selinuntines win victory. Through Zeus we conquer and through Phobos and through Herakles and through Apollo and through Poseidon and through the Tyndaridai and through Athena and through Malophoros and through Pasikrateia and through the other gods, but through Zeus above all. Since there is friendship (it is resolved), that having forged in gold, and having engraved these names, to dedicate in the Apollonion, having written the name of Zeus in first place; and that the gold be sixty talents.

English translation

Jonathan Prag

It is through the gods listed here that the Selinuntines win victory. Through Zeus we conquer and through Phobos and through Herakles and through Apollo and through Poseidon and through the Tyndaridai and through Athena and through Malophoros and through Pasikrateia and through the other gods, but through Zeus above all. Since there is friendship (it is resolved), that having forged in gold, and having engraved these names, to dedicate in the Apollonion, having written the name of Zeus in first place; and that the gold be sixty talents.
